column1: Before 1 January 2022, will the US Intelligence Community publicly state that a laboratory accident is a more probable scenario for the inception of the COVID-19 pandemic than it having emerged naturally through contact with infected animals?
column6: ['Health', 'Foreign Policy', 'US Politics']
Nowhere near ready to make unclassified substantiated claims laying means and methods bare for China and Russia to observer, digest, and break down first principles.

maintaining current forecast

Recent scientific research has strengthened the jump from an animal reservoir hypothesis. According to "Dissecting the early COVID-19 cases in Wuhan,"SCIENCE • 18 Nov 2021 • Vol 374, Issue 6572 • pp. 1202-1204 • DOI: 10.1126/science.abm4454, "...that most early symptomatic cases were linked to Huanan Market—specifically to the western section (1) where raccoon dogs were caged (2)—provides strong evidence of a live-animal market origin of the pandemic." This paper is free to download at https://www.science.org/doi/10.1126/science.abm4454.

Recent reporting of the unnamed intelligence agency considering a lab accident in Wuhan means the discussion is continuing but time is dwindling and the US is focused on domestic politics and soon, turkey.

Declassified intelligence community report released yesterday: https://www.dni.gov/files/ODNI/documents/assessments/Declassified-Assessment-on-COVID-19-Origins.pdf "After examining all available intelligence reporting and other information, though, the IC remains divided on the most likely origin of COVID-19. All agencies assess that two hypotheses are plausible: natural exposure to an infected animal and a laboratory-associated incident." "The IC judges they will be unable to provide a more definitive explanation for the origin of COVID-19 unless new information allows them to determine the specific pathway for initial natural contact with an animal or to determine that a laboratory in Wuhan was handling SARS-CoV-2 or a close progenitor virus before COVID-19 emerged."

We're having some fun now. Three of the Laos coronaviruses were unusual: They carried a molecular hook on their surface that was very similar to the hook on the virus that causes Covid-19, called SARS-CoV-2. Like SARS-CoV-2, their hook allowed them to latch onto human cells....

Flow of news and leaks generally tipping the balance towards lab accident. Pattern of obfuscation and emerging circumstantial evidence (eg the leaked DARPA proposal). As time goes on, it seems likely that we will continue to see more of this kind of information, and less clear evidence supporting alternative hypotheses. Eventually there may be a tipping point where the circumstantial and other evidence quickly shifts public opinion in one direction or the other, at which point US Intelligence community will have to address the claims. However, I don't currently think the tipping point will come before Jan 2022.

Amendment agrees to get to bottom of the Wuhan lab leak theory. Three scenarios:

For this to happen, the IC would need to find substantial new evidence, change their assessment, and also release it publicly. Given the report from late August, the lack of new evidence since then, and the general difficulty of tracing viral origins (e.g. Ebola), the odds of new evidence are maybe at best 5%. I assume the IC would change their assessment at that point, though there may be lag time of a few weeks to verify and disseminate the information. If this all did happen, then it would also need to come out publicly and quickly, which I estimate at a very rough 25% given the existing public information largely came out slowly through FOIA requests. Rounding down because the 5% new evidence estimate is an upper bound.

A kinder, gentler theory on COVID lab leak not due to nefarious gain of function research but, rather, research on risks of viruses moving from animals to humans. A more palatable excuse if one is needed.
IC assessment was inconclusive (... and somewhat pandering to the Chinese government.)

This storyline will not play out well and diversion will be needed.

So the 2% probability may seem inconsistent with what I had just stated, but that comes from the weight I am placing on what may emerge organically outside the official channels - whistleblower reports, citizen investigations etc.

However, " Building on what has already been learned, the next series of studies would include a further examination of the raw data from the earliest cases and sera from potential early cases in 2019. I am revising my estimate fairly significantly downwards from a few weeks ago as the question has become swamped with much evidence and counter-evidence. At this stage, the question certainly seems too inconclusive for the US intelligence community to be in a position to definitively declare the lab-leak hypothesis to be true before the end of the year.

Nature Scientific Reports has recently published a study that suggests the earliest isolates were adapted to facilitate human-to-human transmission.

With a steady stream of articles in WaPo, NYT, Bloomberg on the strongest probability the pandemic jumped from animals to humans, reducing forecast.

The question is specifically stating whether or not the US Intelligence Community will issue a statement on the fact that a laboratory accident is more probable than the zoonotic explanation before Jan 1, 2022 (6 mo.) Lets compare the COVID-19 Pandemic to other similar pandemics.

It is tough to find an adequate base rate for such a scenario, as the COVID-19 pandemic has been relatively unprecedented. Firstly and most importantly, the US Intelligence Community would have to find evidence of the pandemic emerging from a laboratory accident. As it stands, it seems as though the lab-leak scenario is only recognized as a possibility that cannot yet be ruled out (https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-021-01529-3), with the infected animals hypothesis the more likely cause. Disease-causing pathogens have escaped labs before (https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2014/05/when-viruses-escape-the-lab/371202/), but there is not much data from virologists that indicates that the COVID-19 virus was created in a lab. In fact, there is a lack of any signatures of genetic manipulation. Considering all this information, let's say there's a ~20% chance the disease came from a lab.
The outbreak probably started much earlier in China than even they realize.

Dateline 7-1-2021 "The WHO-led team and many other scientists say a natural viral jump from an animal to a human remains the most plausible hypothesis, and a recent study has shown that wild animals susceptible to the virus were sold live at markets in Wuhan." -- https://www.wsj.com/articles/covid-origins-china-wild-animal-farms-pandemic-source-11625060088?mod=djemHL_t
With enough secret accidents of their own, the US should have little incentive to divulge another country’s dirty laundry.
I believe it is worth separately exploring the two questions of (1) whether a lab leak seems probable and (2) whether the US IC would publicly state so.

The downsides of publicly stating that a Chinese lab accident is more probable than not are: (1) Asian Americans already are being increasingly targeted by hate groups on account of the pandemic. This would make it much worse. Indeed, some might be tortured and killed and their businesses damaged on account of such an announcement. These people also vote. (2) This would harm US/China relations without providing any benefit. If the US is serious about pressuring China to ease up on the Uighurs or behave better in the South China Sea, Biden’s foreign policy advisors probably are begging him to prevent any such announcement. (3) This would increase the personal danger to virus researchers around the world, many of whom already are getting death threats, and could lead to reduced research funding, increasing the danger of mass deaths from the next pandemic.

Previous epidemiologic data collected by the NIH shows that approximately 75% of emerging infectious diseases are zoonotic (coming from contact with infected animals), so a base-rate for this being a laboratory accident should be about 25%. However, this only a precedent to the question, how likely is it that the US Intelligence Community will publicly state that a laboratory accident is the more probable scenario. For the IC to take a stance on this issue, they will need more initial case data from China, as initial retrospective data is not laboratory-confirmed and is informed by reporting bias. Given that China has yet to disclose this information for the first phase of the WHO investigation and did not release this data for the 2002 SARS epidemic which originated in China, it is unlikely that the IC will receive the data necessary for a decision. Without this data or alternative sources, they will be restricted to the information that led to their first decision, in which only one member leaned towards it being a laboratory accident and not even with high confidence.

First of all, what is a "laboratory accident"? So many people conflate "laboratory accident" with genetic engineering. The virus could have been released as a result of research activities at any point from sample collection to actual research to waste disposal. If a research worker in the field got Covid by walking into a bat cave to collect bats with insufficient PPE, or when obtaining virus samples from bats outside a bat cave with insufficient PPE or precautions, would either of those be a laboratory accident? Zoonoses and research accidents are not mutually exclusive events, and the concept of "laboratory accident" is vague and poorly defined and is used by very many people to mean many different things. But suppose we say that a laboratory accident means that a sample of the virus was in a laboratory and was released from that laboratory by accident, regardless of whether it was being stored or studied intentionally or whether its presence was incidental to some other work. How would we know whether the virus was released as a result of an accident? We'd know it was released in a lab accident if 1) someone finds a sample of it in a freezer, or 2) the intelligence community finds communications or data showing that someone had it in their freezer (and the only way they'd know that is if they had sequenced it). (Many early sequences were not released publicly, and many early patient samples were ordered destroyed; China was and is not eager to explore this possibility.) A variety of other information would offer supporting evidence, such as if any lab personnel had positive antibody test results very early on (supposedly they didn't, but those tests aren't perfect). There is no "smoking gun" signature of genetic engineering. Furin cleavage sites occur naturally. Moreover, if gain-of-function work was occurring, it would have been done at at least BSL3 if not BSL4, and I would expect that they would know what they are doing. Researchers who work at BSL3 and BSL4 are serious about what they do; accidents do happen but are uncommon. I think the most likely lab accident scenario would be from work characterizing bat coronavirus samples at BSL2, ironically most likely with the goal of understanding and mitigating their pandemic potential. It is also more plausible that BSL2 work could have been done sloppily or that there could have been a mistake. It would be much easier for a high-risk pathogen (that should be handled at BSL4) to escape BSL2 than BSL3 or BSL4. And we know that thousands of bat coronavirus samples were being studied at BSL2 at 2 institutes in Wuhan.
My gut tells me 0% (in decimal percentage points) but gonna follow the wind for the next 7 months.

Interesting. Probable means better than 50% but less than 85% certainty. Right now neither theory is at even odds. The order says the IC look at the data one more time and if no conclusion then provide a list of questions to ask China. To me, this sounds like for form sake let's take one more look but we really need to formally ask again for answers we need from China. Kicks the can down the road to 2022 2d half. Opinion again - this is not an issue that Administration views as needing an urgent resolution. Let it simmer. First the domestic spending gets done, then a victory lap, report comes back, questions to China, Thanksgiving break. And in March 2022 when China responses are inconclusive then another policy review and finally by summer 2022 major sanctions. This to offset the inevitable attacks on democrats as soft on China ahead of 2022 elections.

I believe that Occam's razor applies here. It is now known that the Wuhan lab was pursuing GOF research. It is also known that COVID is unusually contagious for a coronavirus. Thirdly, the CCP has not acted as if this was a naturally occurring virus; they would not have been and continue to be so secretive and argumentative about tracing the origins of the disease if it were of natural origin.
